The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic. Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the evolution of vector-borne diseases in general. It also has implications for the control of plague, as it suggests that the use of human ectoparasites as a vector control measure could be considered.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, to understand the evolution of brain power, we need to know not only the size of the brain but also the number of neurons it contains. This study shows that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by two major shifts in neuron–brain scaling, one with the appearance of birds and mammals and the other with the evolution of birds. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells is not well understood. Here, we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. In these processes, ADF/cofilin is required to sever actin filaments. However, how it does so is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever filaments in a mechanical context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress. We find that the mechanical stress enhances severing, and that the strength of this enhancement depends on the twist of the filaments. We propose that this twist-dependent enhancement of severing is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food-seeking behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island was colonized by different groups from Africa and Asia, with a recent admixture. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island shows that the colonization was not a homogeneous process, and that the genetic structure is also influenced by geography. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar, and they have implications for the study of human migrations and the origin of the Malagasy language. (Show more)

We show that the amount of positive and negative content in a person’s Facebook News Feed influences the emotions of that person and those of their friends. This work has implications for the design of social networks, and for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not translated into proteins, but rather is a component of the cell’s regulatory network. This class of molecules, known as noncoding RNAs, is a major focus of research in the field of molecular biology. One of the most common modifications of noncoding RNAs is the addition of a sugar ring to the Ψ position of uridine nucleotides. We show that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNAs can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings have implications for the function of noncoding RNAs and the regulation of gene expression. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the forces driving the evolution of aquatic mammals have been difficult to test quantitatively. We show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic medium and is constrained by energetic limitations. These results provide a quantitative basis for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggest that the evolution of body size in aquatic vertebrates is a general phenomenon.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to attach to surfaces and to induce the production of virulence factors and biofilm. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the regulation of bacterial surface attachment and pathogenicity. They also have implications for understanding the role of type IV pili in bacterial pathogenesis.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide problem, which is of particular importance for surface water quality. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the biological integrity of global water resources. The results of this study are of great importance for the development of future policy measures.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been detected in a variety of animal species, including deer. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. They highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study also demonstrates the importance of a global, coordinated, and sustained effort to monitor the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals. This will be critical to detect and contain future outbreaks. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed. We propose a set of innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is still poorly understood, and the role of the intraneuronal Aβ in the AD pathogenesis is largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a major source of proinflammatory factors, which are critical for the recruitment of microglia and the initiation of the AD-associated inflammatory response. Our findings provide a novel perspective on the AD pathogenesis, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for our understanding of the evolution of this species. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the earliest known site of economic exploitation of chickens is the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. We show that the frequency of chicken bones at this site is much higher than at any other site in the Southern Levant, and that the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones is a result of the high frequency of adult individuals. We further argue that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood in detail. This study shows that a large protein folds through distinct steps, each of which is a native-like intermediate. The steps are not necessarily sequential, but the intermediates are not transient. The results suggest that the steps are not independent, but are part of a common process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap structure on Np4-capped RNAs is also critical for the rapid degradation of those transcripts. This enzyme, which is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate, is a pyrophosphohydrolase that prefers to remove the terminal phosphate from Np4-capped RNAs over the triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This unique mode of substrate recognition positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. The differential impact of this enzyme on the rates at which capped and uncapped termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Our findings may also have implications for other conditions in which arginine deprivation is involved in the development of immunosuppression. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet, and that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also provide a quantitative basis for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which it is difficult to influence its dynamics. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering, and that the electronic bandgap can be tuned continuously from 5.6 eV to 0 eV. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is a major advance in the field of plant disease control. This study describes the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are highly diverse in sequence and structure. The structure of one of the peptides is reported here for the first time. The peptide was found to be highly active against plant fungal pathogens, and it was shown to bind to phosphoinositides, which are important components of the fungal cell wall.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrate that female contributions to sperm proteome composition are extensive. Our findings provide a foundation for future studies that will help us understand the extent to which sperm and FRT proteomes are similar and the extent to which they differ. This information will be critical for understanding the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and for developing new strategies for improving reproductive success.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of mutations in VWF, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is the first demonstration of a mechanism for the effects of force on protein binding. This work provides a framework for understanding the effects of force on other proteins. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to investigate the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, and we find that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The results of this study will help to improve the representation of ACI in climate models. This will help to improve our understanding of the climate system. This will also help to improve the prediction of climate change.

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key issue in understanding the origin and early evolution of life. The isotopic record of the paleotemperatures of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the accuracy of the isotopic record, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for assessing the temperature history inferred from the isotopic record by using the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Less)

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to regulate ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channel C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion flow by ion channels. They also provide a possible mechanism for the BK channel’s normal closing and its unique properties of fast activation and slow inactivation. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. One of the most important steps in the parasite life cycle is the invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), which is a critical energy barrier to overcome. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, and this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the malaria parasite is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a potential target for the development of new therapies. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by mechanical strain, and that the electronic properties can be tuned by strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between electronic and phonon properties of diamond, and for developing machine-learning methods for predicting the properties of materials. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. We show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza prevention. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does this remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may help to explain the speed with which the brain can process language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and cell fate. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we provide a detailed characterization of the circuit that promotes overeating in mice. We show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) inhibits dopamine neurons, thereby reducing the activity of dopamine neurons and promoting eating. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we have identified a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for future studies of the neural basis of overeating and obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2-fixation) is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle. However, the vast majority of plants are incapable of N2-fixation, and the few that are capable are limited in their ability to fix N2 in the field. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in a plant symbiosis, allowing the bacteria to be controlled in a manner that is specific to the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen cycle in agriculture.

The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are a critical tool for forest monitoring and policy, but they are often generated too late to prevent deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced forest loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also demonstrate that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C of warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. Our results indicate that the health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are much larger than the climate benefits. This study provides a quantitative assessment of the health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols. It also provides a framework for future studies on the health and climate impacts of other pollutants. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. Here we report a recombinant protein-based vaccine that can be produced at a low cost and can be presented on a virus-like particle to enhance immunogenicity. This engineered protein has the potential to be a cost-effective vaccine for global access. (Show more)

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrALK, is a ligand for the zebrafish homolog of ALK/LTK, DrLtk. We further show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a link between the evolutionarily conserved ALK/LTK family of receptors and the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is of interest for the understanding of the role of ALK/LTK family members in human diseases.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humanity. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of plague during its formative years, from the time it emerged from its progenitor to the time it was first described in the literature. We show that the emergence of plague was a long and complex process, and that the pathogen’s early evolution and ecology were highly dynamic. This study provides a better understanding of the origins of plague and its impact on human history. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the evolution of other pathogens. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also provide a framework for understanding the relationship between masculinity and political attitudes more generally.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 80% of the world’s grasslands and the conversion of 90% of the world’s arable land to intensive crop production. This has resulted in the release of massive amounts of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. We show that the adoption of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on Mollisols worldwide can increase soil C storage and the use of soil C by microbes. These practices can therefore play a key role in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and cause disease in humans. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by identifying SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for the pandemic, as one of the highest-ranking spillover candidates. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be of interest to policy makers and health scientists. We hope that it will be used to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators and is often used to infer the identity of the plant’s pollinator. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a convergent evolution of the red nectar trait in two other plants visited by nectar-feeding vertebrates. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is a simple and effective way for plants to attract pollinators.

The genetic structure of Europe is a major topic of current research. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. Our results indicate that they had a genetic ancestry that is not represented in modern European populations. In addition, we show that the genetic history of Europe is more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future bat-to-human spillover events. (Show more)

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in this resource-scarce setting. Our findings highlight the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. This process is carried out by the lagging strand DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. (Show more)
The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other cities and other types of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to researchers and practitioners interested in urban change.

COVID-19 is a new disease, and the pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, was given to the patients, and the results showed that it was effective in reducing mortality. This study provides a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to eukaryotic cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of these mechanisms in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes is not. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the sequestration of copper, and that the secreted isocyanide products of this cluster have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of fungal interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

Silica is a major component of the Martian surface, and its origin and distribution are important to understanding the history of the planet. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. We report the detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, and its cogenetic detrital feldspar and cristobalite, which are possibly derived from silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The presence of primary amorphous silica, and possibly sulfate and oxide precipitates, suggests that the Martian surface has been subject to multiple aqueous processes.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate change, and that the vulnerability of forests to frost damage is increasing in Europe and Asia, but not in North America. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that these cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis and suggest that targeting Th17 cells may be a useful strategy for the treatment of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate motor neuron toxicity and improve ALS disease modeling and drug discovery. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the human granulocytic anaplasmosis bacterium induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of the bacterium to colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. It also provides a framework for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The discovery of a new basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group and the evolution of the avian body plan. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. (Less)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without a detailed understanding of the processes that are involved. In this paper, we show that one of the most important processes in the climate system is the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing temperature there. This increase in water vapor is a feedback that increases the rate of warming in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads). We also describe a new mechanism for the evolution of color change, and we introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the ability of cancer cells to form tumor-initiating cells. We show that hypoxia induces expression of the ALKBH5 demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. This, in turn, leads to the formation of tumor-initiating cells, which are responsible for the initiation of tumor growth. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a target for cancer therapy.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles to the present day.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depend on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and the main site of nutrient absorption. Therefore, intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) are crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis. However, the intestinal epithelium is constantly exposed to a variety of environmental stimuli, and the regulation of IECs is a complex process. Here, we focus on the role of retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) in IECs and demonstrate that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides insights into the regulation of IECs and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, at 3.8-Å resolution. We find that the receptor binds to the spike in a manner similar to SARS-CoV, and that the structure of the complex is similar to that of the receptor bound to the SARS-CoV spike. We also find that the receptor binds to the D614G mutant spike, but not to the wild-type spike, suggesting that the D614G mutation may improve the binding of the mutant spike to the receptor. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are the starting point for the study of chemical reactions and the understanding of the properties of chemical compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a contribution to the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the global carbon cycle is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has acted to warm climate and to reduce the rate of warming in recent decades. Our results suggest that fire suppression and active fire management can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. However, with climate change, more extreme fires are likely to occur, which could lead to a reversal of the positive effects of fire on the carbon cycle. This highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of fire in the global carbon cycle in a changing climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of a specific symbiont, and to maintain the stability of the mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its symbiotic bacterium Vibrio fischeri. We propose that this type of regulation may be a general feature of symbioses, and that it may be used by hosts to control the activities of their symbionts.

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and draws on the strengths of topic modeling and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that our method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The current understanding of this pandemic is that it was the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Our analysis provides evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the disease was not established in Europe before the arrival of the next plague pandemic. Our results challenge the current understanding of the origins of the second plague pandemic. (Show more)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a rapidly spreading disease that has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the sea stars themselves. The virus is likely spread by the movement of infected sea stars, and the disease is likely to continue to spread as long as the virus is present.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of blood cancer, and the prognosis is poor. We have previously shown that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on AML stem cells in a large proportion of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island was colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The distribution of the diversity across the island shows that the colonization was not a homogeneous process, and that the genetic structure is also not homogeneous. These results suggest that the island was colonized by different groups of people, and that the process of colonization was not a homogeneous process. This is important for the understanding of the history of Madagascar.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete with each other. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential contribution to the development of antiviral and vaccine strategies.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information on crop status, but are often underutilized due to their subjective nature. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of many crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC survey can be used to provide a more complete picture of crop status and provide a more accurate assessment of crop condition. This information can be used to improve the accuracy of yield forecasts and to better manage agricultural production.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major source of carbon dioxide (CO2) to the atmosphere, and its response to climate change is of critical importance for predicting future changes in the global carbon cycle. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to parasitism is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because of the difficulty in obtaining information about the past. Here, we show that the transition to parasitism is linked to a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the functional capacity of the genome. Our findings provide a new perspective on the evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the origin of life. They also suggest that the transition to parasitism may have been accompanied by a relaxation of selection on the genome, which may have facilitated the emergence of the first cells.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa is assessed using a high-resolution large ensemble. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of improving the representation of the complex dynamics of the South African rainfall system in climate models. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the Trinity test, provides a link between the laboratory synthesis of quasicrystals and the discovery of quasicrystals in nature.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The biosynthesis of the photosynthetic pigments, bacteriochlorophyll and bacteriopheophytin, is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest period in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur during warm conditions. We also find that anthropogenic forcings have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. This finding suggests that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created acute human and ecosystem impacts in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes and a variety of environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms of autism. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 Ca2+ sensor that lead to constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and to a syndrome of hematological abnormalities. We also identify mutations in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that lead to a milder form of the same syndrome. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the CRAC channel, and suggest new avenues for the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process and is thought to be a major contributor to the loss of neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and the subsequent accumulation of aggregates within other neurons. We also show that the internalization of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is thought to protect them from infectious diseases. However, this study provides evidence that the submandibular salivary gland of the bat is a site for the accumulation of immunosuppressant proteins, which facilitate the establishment of microbial communities in the bat. This study also provides evidence that these immunosuppressant proteins can be targeted to promote viral infection. This study provides a deeper understanding of the immune system of bats and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of viral diseases in humans and animals. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that it blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in a cancer cell-line screen, and that a subset of B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Finally, we show that a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma makes these cells uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable aggregation state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, and can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the history of life, and the study of the origin of plants is of great importance. The Cretaceous is also a time of great environmental change, and the study of the origin of plants in this period is important for understanding the evolution of plants in a changing environment. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous of Spain, has led to a better understanding of the origin of plants and the evolution of aquatic plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is of great interest to understand the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all known viruses. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the most recent common ancestor of all known viruses is much older than previously thought. We also show that the rate of substitution in the viral genome is much lower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique source of information for the study of ancient human health and disease. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, and shows that this rate is consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections. The paper also shows that the rate of sea level rise is not uniform around the globe, but varies by as much as 0.2 mm/y2. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, and shows that this rate is consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections.
