Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has declined with age in the elderly, but has increased with age in the midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We find that the increase in pain with age is more pronounced for those with less education, and that this increase is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a major goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, and to provide insight into the mechanistic pathways of enzymes. This work also demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the mechanism of a reaction that is not amenable to kinetic analysis. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) continues to cause severe respiratory disease, with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibitor, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of a specific symbiont, and to maintain the stability of the mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its symbiotic bacterium Vibrio fischeri. We propose that this type of regulation may be a general feature of symbioses, and that it may be used by hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities.

This paper describes a series of experiments and a field trial that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention on teachers’ mindsets about discipline. The intervention was designed to be scalable and to be implemented by teachers themselves. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three school systems. The intervention halved suspension rates in the first year and bolstered the respect of suspended students for their teachers. These findings have implications for the future of school discipline and for the future of teacher education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is known to cause a variety of genomic mutations. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe respiratory pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. To understand the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus-surface spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may inform the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries have a significant impact on the environment and their own health. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can lead to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and that the effect is concentrated among the lowest quartile of diners. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in cafeterias and other catering outlets could make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving population health.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment that is remodeled by a variety of mechanisms in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major contribution to the field of cancer biology.

In response to the coronavirus pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response, and it is possible that this is due to the actions of accessory proteins such as ORF8. The structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 provides insight into how this protein may interfere with the host immune response. The structure also provides a basis for the design of future antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1). This leads to the activation of astrocytes, which in turn up-regulate aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), leading to an increase in water influx into astrocytes and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also provide a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (Show more)

The era of big data has led to a new challenge in statistical inference: How do we properly assess the strength of associations that we find in a data set? This is a problem of selective inference: We have “cherry-picked” the data, so we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help readers to understand the strengths and limitations of the methods that they use in their own work.

The development of vascular ECs is a major challenge in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Here, we report the generation of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts by a single factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new therapeutic approach for vascular disorders. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides a valuable model for studying the development of vascular ECs. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. This study demonstrates that the ligands augmentor-α1, augmentor-α2, and augmentor-β are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. In addition, we show that augmentor-α2 and augmentor-β are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a basis for further understanding of the function of these ligands in vivo.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple causes and mechanisms. In this study, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our findings provide a new perspective for the understanding of the pathogenesis of T2D and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza and cause occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, including disturbed flow. The present study demonstrates that disturbed flow activates the YAP/TAZ pathway in the endothelium to promote the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, in the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural and important part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major cause of ecosystem degradation. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the need for increased awareness and management of human-caused wildfires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other cities and other types of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to researchers and practitioners interested in urban change.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that have been used for pest control in agriculture and domestic settings. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, and demonstrated that this channel is also involved in the avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular basis for the use of natural repellents in pest control, and also highlights the importance of the evolution of the TRP channel family in arthropod–plant interactions. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. Our study shows that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is a direct consequence of the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts and thus provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching. Our findings have implications for our ability to predict the fate of coral reefs under climate change and may ultimately help us to conserve this important ecosystem.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and the first line of defense against infections. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also the main site of tumorigenesis in Drosophila. We identify a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment triggers a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn triggers the growth of the tumor. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the microbiome can regulate the activity of the epithelium, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the second leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is a major determinant of the survival of patients. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this up-regulation is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1. We also show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can inhibit the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, and that this antibody can inhibit the growth of breast cancer patient-derived xenografts in mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key event in the history of the last ice age, but the cause is still debated. We show that the start of deglaciation was linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in the Southern Hemisphere climate system.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and sustainability assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, including the catch of all species, and show that they provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. Our analysis reveals that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost during development, and the adult nervous system is incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is reminiscent of a form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings provide a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in the control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. They also suggest that the mammalian nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult nervous system may be more capable of regeneration than previously thought.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in yeast and mice. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in yeast, suggesting that the initiation of recombination in eukaryotes may be conserved.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the organization of the human brain. This hypothesis is based on the assumption that the brain is organized in a small number of topographically similar networks, which are active during rest. In this study, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to validate the RSN hypothesis in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant RSN was already reduced at diagnosis, and this abnormality progressed over time. These results provide a direct link between the metabolic organization of the brain and the function of the brain. They also provide a possible explanation for the development of cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export from the nucleus. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally, and that it is not modified at the 3′ end. These results define a second 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disorder that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a target for the management of this disorder.

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds, and the fruit is a major source of food flavor. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of the volatile compounds in tomato fruit are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a pathway for the biosynthesis of aliphatic and aromatic nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is unique among the known pathways for the production of these compounds, and it provides a model for the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatile compounds.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems, and because it is frequently considered in isolation from biodiversity loss. Our results have important implications for the future of ecosystems, and for the ability of ecosystems to provide services that underpin human well-being.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a map of local space, which is represented by grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. How these cell types are organized anatomically is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior in mice. We found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but weakly linked to other cell types. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the space-map in MEC. They also provide a platform for future studies of the function of the space-map in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine-containing system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing system of the human brain is organized in a manner that is distinct from that in the animal brain. In particular, we demonstrate that the dopamine-containing system of the human brain is organized in a manner that is distinct from that in the animal brain.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to signal their connection to others. This finding has implications for our understanding of social connection, as well as for the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its automaticity is regulated by a number of factors. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a regulator of the automaticity of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated for decades. In this study, we demonstrate that Si can enhance the resistance of rice against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest control. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results provide a link between tetrahydrobiopterin and ether lipid metabolism and suggest that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is a potential target for the modulation of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the successful delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment locus of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the field of plant biology.

Nutrient inputs to lakes and coastal ecosystems are often dominated by small tributaries, which drain surrounding watersheds. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large rivers and lakes, leaving small tributaries largely unstudied. We show that the nutrient loads and bioavailability of nutrients from small tributaries are high for their size, suggesting that they may play a greater role in fueling coastal algal blooms than previously thought. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs and emphasize the need to address nutrient management in these systems. This is especially important for large water bodies, such as Lake Michigan, where the majority of the nutrient load comes from small tributaries.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of interacting particles in a random potential, and we discuss the possible relevance of this analogy for the study of the dynamics of complex systems.

This study provides a detailed description of the effects of a specific type of autoimmune encephalitis on the brain’s electrical activity. It also offers a detailed description of the underlying mechanisms, which may be relevant to other autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbation events is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon over a large area of the ocean floor and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of global warming and the history of carbon perturbation events. They also provide a link between the history of carbon perturbation events and the history of global warming. (Show more)

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire is unclear. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33% from 2001 to 2015. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The genetic basis of sex in vertebrates is a key component of the evolution of sexual dimorphism and sexual selection. In this study, we investigate the effects of a single genetic locus on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with multiple sex classes. We find that the genetic basis of sex in this species produces a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of secondary sexual characteristics. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of toxic species that are generated by the photoreceptor cell’s light-driven metabolism. This study shows that the levels of iron in the retina, as reflected in the expression of the transferrin receptor, impacts the levels of bisretinoids, a class of toxic species that are formed by the oxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium’s photoreceptor cell-derived lipids. This study also shows that iron can promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids, which can lead to the loss of photoreceptor cells. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of retinal diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization in predators is often considered a dead end. Here we show that specialization can evolve in a modular way, and that specialization on one prey type can evolve into specialization on a different prey type. Our results help to understand the evolution of specialization in predators, and how it has shaped the present-day food web structure.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that it is effective in cancer. We also show that the inhibitor is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic target and a mechanism of action for a cancer drug, and have identified a potential target for drug development.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is an important finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results have implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show here that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
